labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Abstract
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body: Maybe use the first sentence of the Introduction as the initial Abstract.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: Agree

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Care to craft a PR for review?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Done

issues.title: Ombudsteam confidentiality
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
The Ombudsteam has strict confidentiality rules. I suggest that in https://github.com/larseggert/moderation/blob/main/draft-ecahc-moderation.md#relation-to-ombudsteam we should say something like:

The Ombudsteam has strict rules of confidentiality. If a moderation case overlaps with an Ombudsteam case, confidential information SHOULD NOT be shared between the teams unless there is no practical alternative. In any such case, the members of the moderation team MUST treat this information according to the Ombudsteam rules {{BCP25}}.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: LGTM. Do you want to do a PR or should I?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Please go ahead, I haven't cloned the repo.

issues.title: Public process and development of those
issues.author: JayDaley
issues.body: I suggest adding a section on the team being required to publish and maintain a public process document and to consult with the community on any changes to that

issues.title: Strengthen separation of powers
issues.author: JayDaley
issues.body: I suggest strengthening the separation of powers between this team and IESG/IAB membership from a SHOULD to a MUST and adding LLC Board and Trustees to the exclusion list.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: Makes sense

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Care to craft a PR?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Also, IESG and IAB are in the appeals path, but LLC and Trust are not. FWIW.

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: I agree about adding the LLC and Trust. It's not necessarily only about the appeal chain, but about the perception that "the leadership" may be "censoring" the community. Better to have it be clean.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
~~Ok with me. Could you prep a PR?~~

@coopdanger scratch that. I reworked #10 - please take a look?

issues.title: What about interactions with NomCom
issues.author: JayDaley
issues.body: The doc is silent on any potential interactions with NomCom and it may be sensible to address those.  For example, if someone stood for a role and the moderation team had received abusive private messages from that person in relation to a moderation action, then they should be allowed to tell NomCom about that.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body:
I'm not sure about this. To begin with there's some confidentiality text in the Ombudusteam relation section that would contradict this advice.

Secondly, isn't there a more general issue that anyone in the IETF, when providing nomcom feedback, may use the context they have with the candidate (public and private) to provide feedback? Of course naturally omitting any sensitive details, but ... this isn't specific to the moderators. If I'm a WG chair and I don't like the interactions with person X, that may reflect on my nomcom feedback for X.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, anyone who's had negative (or positive) private dealings with a candidate can choose to share that with NomCom. I don't see that dealings with the moderation team are more confidential than any other private dealing. (That is *not* true for the Ombudsteam, however.)

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Discussion so far seems to lean towards closing this issue with no action - or does someone want to propose a PR with a change?

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: I think we should close without a change.

issues.title: Be clearer about what's unified
issues.author: jariarkko
issues.body:
The introduction starts with "This document proposes the creation of a moderator team for all of the IETF's various contribution channels." And the motivation part starts with ombudsteam/harrassment and continues to discuss moderation, split between different moderators on various WGs and lists, and PR-actions.

I don't feel the document does a good job of explaining what's actually being unified in a single team. Intro seems to imply it is the different types of channels. When we started the email thread I thought this was about all non-WG lists and different tooling (chat etc). Scope section seems to say that it is all lists and meetings and chat. But the ombudsteam part is still clearly not in it.

I think there's some room for discussion here perhaps on what we are actually proposing. Are WGs in it or not? And WG meetings? I'm fine whatever the answer is but we should be clear about it. (I do think though that tracking all WG lists may be a large task for a single moderation team.)

I think the introduction should clearly lay out what the unification is, e.g., 

OLD:
This document proposes the creation of a moderator team for all of the IETF's various contribution channels.
NEW:
This document proposes the creation of a moderator team for all of the IETF's various contribution channels. This includes all WG and other mailing lists, chat and other virtual presence tools, and all virtual and in-person meeting activities. The moderator team will work with the ombudsteam that continues to be in charge of addressing any harassment that may occur in the IETF.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
> I do think though that tracking all WG lists may be a large task for a single moderation team.

It's impossible, not "large". That's why I think the normal mode should be that WG Chairs initally handle a case and then call in the moderators if the issue continues.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: The original idea was to have this team do *everything*, including WGs. This would of course rely on chairs and participants who flag problematic behavior to the team. (Whether chairs still MAY/SHOULD take action themselves is IMO TBD, I can make arguments both ways.)

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Yes, I understand that but let me quote my whole email on this point:

> "TODO: Decide whether moderation rights remain also with WG chairs, list admins, and others who currently have them, or whether all moderation rights centralize with the moderator team. I somewhat prefer the latter, since it'll be cleaner."
> 
> I think that some WG chairs might like this, and others might hate it as reducing their role. How about saying that a WG Chair MAY invoke the moderator team at any time after a disruptive message exchange starts and SHOULD do so if the matter is not resolved within one week?
>
> Otherwise I fear that we will have created an unscalable solution, rather than providing assistance to WGs in difficulty. (Do we have any data on how many disruptive message exchanges are in progress at any one time?)

Just think how big the team would need to be to watch all WG lists! I really don't see any alternative to having WG chairs or list admins call them in when needed (or any participant if the chairs/admins are inactive).

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Agreed. But the thing we need to decide on is if chairs/admins can/should still do their own moderation, or if their (new) role is to merely alert the moderator team and let them take action.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Maybe that should be an open question in the draft, so that WG Chairs themselves can express an opinion?
Personally, if I was still a WG Chair, I think I'd want the right to attempt moderation, with the "professional" team as backup. But other WG chairs might have a different opinion.

issues.title: Moderation criteria and processes
issues.author: coopdanger
issues.body: I think in Section 4.1 or elsewhere this document needs to say something about how the moderation team will develop its criteria and processes, and how much community review will be involved before those are finalized. It may be important to explicitly state that those things should be living documents and not RFCs.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Good idea. Could you prep a PR?

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: Sure.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
> The moderator team's criteria and 
> processes SHALL be developed with community input _and made public_

(I'm not quite sure how to patch a PR...)

issues.title: Core set of channels for proactive monitoring
issues.author: coopdanger
issues.body: Should the document specify a core set of channels that the moderator team will proactively monitor? Say, ietf@ and last-call@, at a minimum?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Good idea. Could you prep a PR?

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: Sure. Do you think those two are the minimal set or are there others that you would want the team to keep an eye on? Any Zulip or Slack channels? Or maybe some catch-all to describe the general channels where you want them to proactively monitor?

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: Yes I think that PR is fine and we can adopt it and close this issue.

issues.title: Repos, wikis, etc.
issues.author: coopdanger
issues.body: The intro says that moderation procedures for Github repos, wikis, etc. are undefined -- and then doesn't define anything to address this. Should a placeholder at least be included to note this for further discussion?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I had hoped that talking about "all participation channels" would make this clear, but maybe it's not clear enough? Suggestions welcome.

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body:
This is the part that confuses me:

> This IETF moderator team consists of a small number of individuals (no less than three) that SHALL moderate all the IETF's various current and future participation channels. At present, those include mailing lists, chat channels, and in-person and remote meetings.

The first sentence says "all" but the second sentence does not include Github or wikis. Are they supposed to be included or not?

Also, what does it mean that the moderators have to moderate in-person and remote meetings. Does their remit extend to live interactions at the mic? Does it include interim meetings? I suspect it might be simpler to leave WG chairs (or other conveners of meetings, like the IAB) with moderator privileges for live conduct. However, live conduct could potentially factor into a pattern of behavior that the IETF moderator team deals with that also includes textual interactions.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: Again, I agree with Alissa. We can't reasonably take the WG chairs and the like out of their role of managing a meeting. Doesn't mean that moderators cannot be consulted or learn about patterns, etc.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body:
Maybe:

This IETF moderator team consists of a small number of individuals (no less than three) that SHALL moderate all the IETF's various current and future participation channels. At present, those include mailing lists, chat channels, and discussions in other systems that the IETF or the WGs have chosen to employ, such as GitHub, Wikis, and issue trackers.

The management and moderation of in-person, remote, and interim meetings remains a task of the relevant group's management, such as WG chairs. However, it is expected that moderators are available for consultation and assistance should issues arise, and may confer with the group management over potential patterns of behavior.

issues.title: Confidential information
issues.author: coopdanger
issues.body: I do not think confidential information should be shared between the ombudsteam and the moderator team under any circumstances.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
My concern is that there might be cases where moderation is being gamed as a form of harassment. So the Ombudsteam might _need_ to warn the moderation team that something stinky is going on. And if they do that, they will need to name individuals. That needs to be treated as strictly confidential information by the moderators.

This isn't transitive: moderation is mainly a public operation anyway.

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: I think this is probably a tiny corner case and it's not worth sacrificing the ombudsteam's confidentiality obligation over it. It can be scary enough to approach an ombudsperson with a complaint; having the confidentiality circle extend to an extra set of people whom the complainant does not trust could be a deterrent to people using the ombudsteam.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: FWIW I agree 100% with Alissa on this

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body:
Maybe:

OLD:
If a moderation case overlaps with an ombudsteam case, confidential information SHOULD NOT be shared between the teams unless there is no practical alternative. In any such case, the members of the moderation team MUST treat this information according to the ombudsteam rules {{!RFC7776}}.
NEW:
If a moderation case overlaps with an ombudsteam case, confidential information MUST NOT be shared between the teams.

issues.title: Appeals chain clarification
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
>  Decisions by the IETF Chair can be appealed to the IESG as a whole, again per {{!RFC2026}}.

Should we clarify that the appeals chain potentially extends to IAB and ISOC Board? (This is not clarified in RFC 9245 either.)

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: We left it out in 9245, because it's specified in 2026 already.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
But the text could be misunderstood to imply *only* the IESG part of the
appeal chain. (Don't delay the draft for this.)

(via tiny screen & keyboard)
Regards,
        Brian Carpenter

On Thu, 6 Jul 2023, 19:32 Lars Eggert, ***@***.***> wrote:

> We left it out in 9245, because it's specified in 2026 already.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/larseggert/moderation/issues/17#issuecomment-1623138331>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABMKET7HYGPEPE54UDQU4CLXOZSZLANCNFSM6AAAAAAZ7PM2FI>
> .
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I don't think so? We only have one appeals process (2026) and that doesn't end with the IESG.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body:
I think the text is a bit handwavy. Maybe:

Disagreements with a decision by the IETF Chair can be brought to the attention of the IETF Chair. If this does lead to a resolution, the decision can be appealed as described in {{!RFC2026}}, as with any other Area Director decision. In this case the appeals chain starts with an appeal to the IESG as a whole.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
Do you mean

> Disagreements with a decision by the IETF Chair can be brought to the attention of the IETF Chair. If this does lead to a resolution,

*not* lead to a resolution?

> the decision can be appealed as described in {{!RFC2026}}, as with any other Area Director decision. In this case the appeals chain starts with an appeal to the IESG as a whole.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: Right of course :-)

issues.title: minor edit to Jari's contact info
issues.author: jariarkko
issues.body:
Please add:

city: Kauniainen 
code: "02700" 
country: FI

issues.title: Email suggestions from @richsalz
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body:
[Email suggestions](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gendispatch/3m1ny_Zjhxfy8vTqp14cSgQsO84) from @richsalz:
>I am posting to the gendispatch list because that is where the document says discussion should happen.
> 
>In Section 3, Motivation, the MODML reference doesn’t really give guidance to chairs for this general case being discussed by >this document. It describes how WG chairs should act if they make their WG list moderated, which is different.
> 
>The term PR-Action should be defined when first used, I think.
> 
>In section 4.1, Scope, the sentence “If is not expected that the moderator team will be monitoring every IETF channel…” should appear much earlier in the document.
> 
>In Section 4.3, Appeals, this sentence confuses me: Disagreements with a decision by the IETF Chair can be brought to their attention.  Does “their” refer to the IETF Chair? And if so, is it reasonable to expect that the IETF Chair having decided will change their mind? Isn’t disagreements with IETF Chair decisions can be appealed?
> 
>Have you considered having some subset of the organizational bodies and ISOC appoint members or liaisons?

issues.title: Email suggestions from @ekr
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body:
[Email suggestions](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gendispatch/x1JcEWRYy8_NXE07DqdkCWXr1lQ) from @ekr:
```
I think this is a good idea and this draft is a good start. I have
made a few comments below, but I want to make one general suggestion
for enhancement.

In my experience one of the things that makes moderation difficult
is when each moderation decision is itself subject to extensive
debate in the same venue as it is happening. This constitutes a
DoS on the venue as well as discouraging strong moderation. I
think it would be good to establish a separate venue for debating
moderation discussions (e.g., an issue tracker or something)
that is distinct from the lists being moderated. This will allow
for public debate where necessary but not subject everyone else to it.


S 4.1.
   The moderator team SHALL operate according to a consistent and
   uniform set of criteria, processes, and actions.  The moderator team
   SHALL independently define and execute their role.  They SHALL
   maintain a public set of moderation criteria, processes, actions, and
   other material that allows the community to understand and comment on
   the role of the team.  The moderator team SHOULD consider adopting
   moderation criteria, processes, and actions that other technical
   communities have found suitable.  The moderator team's criteria and
   processes SHALL be developed with community input, but they are not
   expected to be documented in the RFC series.

So these do not require approval of IAB or IESG?

   The moderator team MAY initiate moderation actions by itself;
   individual participants SHOULD also alert the team to disruptive
   behavior they observe.  Participants should be able to contact the
   moderator team in ways that are, ideally, integrated into the various
   participation channels the IETF offers.

I think you should clarify that this is confidential.


Maybe I'm missing it, but it's not clear to me what the *powers*
of moderators are. For instance, can they ban someoen entirely
from a list? From an IETF list? It just seems to say "moderation
actions". FWIW my view is they should have quite broad powers.



S 4.2.

   Because the IESG and IAB are in the appeals chain for moderator team
   decisions (see Section 4.3), the IETF Chair SHOULD NOT appoint a
   moderator who is serving on the IESG or IAB.

I think this should probably be a MUST and I would change it to
forbid someone becoming a moderator and then joining the I*.

   Because the IESG and IAB are in the appeals chain for moderator team
   decisions (see Section 4.3), serving members of the IESG and IAB
   MUST NOT serve as moderators.

I don't see a clause that allows replacing moderators. That seems
like it needs to exist.

S 4.4.
   Due to the global nature of the IETF, the membership of this team
   SHOULD reflect a diversity of time zones and other participant
   characteristics that lets it operate effectively around the clock and
   throughout the year.  Team diversity is also important to ensure any
   participant observing problematic behavior can identify a moderator
   they feel comfortable contacting.

This seems to implicitly assume a very high level of responsiveness
(24x7). I'm not sure that's necessary but if you think it is, then
you should say so.
```

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
And @mnot responded with
```
Piggybacking additional feedback on EKR's because I agree with much^H^H^H^Hall of it.

> On 7 Jul 2023, at 6:04 am, Eric Rescorla <ekr@rtfm.com> wrote:
[...]
> In my experience one of the things that makes moderation difficult
> is when each moderation decision is itself subject to extensive
> debate in the same venue as it is happening. This constitutes a
> DoS on the venue as well as discouraging strong moderation. I
> think it would be good to establish a separate venue for debating
> moderation discussions (e.g., an issue tracker or something)
> that is distinct from the lists being moderated. This will allow
> for public debate where necessary but not subject everyone else to it.

This is a very good suggestion, provided that we very firmly move that discussion there. I'm not sure folks have the discipline.

> S 4.1.
>    The moderator team SHALL operate according to a consistent and
>    uniform set of criteria, processes, and actions.  The moderator team
>    SHALL independently define and execute their role.  They SHALL
>    maintain a public set of moderation criteria, processes, actions, and
>    other material that allows the community to understand and comment on
>    the role of the team.  The moderator team SHOULD consider adopting
>    moderation criteria, processes, and actions that other technical
>    communities have found suitable.  The moderator team's criteria and
>    processes SHALL be developed with community input, but they are not
>    expected to be documented in the RFC series.
> 
> So these do not require approval of IAB or IESG?

This is perhaps the most important point. In the past, there have been very strong disagreements about moderation, and questioning of legitimacy of particular actions within the IETF process. Allowing the moderators to 'define [...] their role' and 'adopt moderation criteria' outside of the IETF consensus process opens up a number of questions about how that works, whether the output is legitimate in the eyes of the community, etc. 

> Maybe I'm missing it, but it's not clear to me what the *powers*
> of moderators are. For instance, can they ban someoen entirely
> from a list? From an IETF list? It just seems to say "moderation
> actions". FWIW my view is they should have quite broad powers.

Yes. It'd also be helpful if this draft listed the RFCs the authors believe will be updated or obsoleted if it is published.

> S 4.4.
>    Due to the global nature of the IETF, the membership of this team
>    SHOULD reflect a diversity of time zones and other participant
>    characteristics that lets it operate effectively around the clock and
>    throughout the year.  Team diversity is also important to ensure any
>    participant observing problematic behavior can identify a moderator
>    they feel comfortable contacting.
> 
> This seems to implicitly assume a very high level of responsiveness
> (24x7). I'm not sure that's necessary but if you think it is, then
> you should say so.

If WG chairs lose the ability to moderate (which I know is an open question), handling an issue through a moderator team is going to inevitably add latency. So I think it is necessary -- IME it's much more effective if bad behaviour is caught and stopped early.

To that question of whether WG chairs should still be able to moderate -- I'm not sure, but I observe very different behaviour in different WGs. What passes in some WGs as normal debate would be flagged by chairs as disruptive. Will moderators appreciate these differences, or set a new level for some WGs? And what will that level be?

Whether or not WG chairs still have the ability to moderate, it'd be good to understand what the expected interactions between chairs and moderators would be. E.g., will moderators check in with chairs on a proposed resolution, to get context and assure that it will work in that community? If chairs retain the ability to moderate, do they need to inform moderators when they act? Etc.

Finally, an editorial nit: I found Section very difficult to read, in part due to the liberal sprinkling of references throughout the text. It might help to move references to the end of the applicable sentence, where possible.


```

issues.title: Email suggestions from John Levine
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body:
[Email suggestions](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gendispatch/2H9subWDn6IRvkXAPhCT54PF6d8) from John Levine:
```
While I think the idea of this draft is fine, I do not understand the 2119 language.

In other RFCs, 2119 language tells you how to interoperate.  You MUST do this or
your system won't interoperate with others.  But here, for example:

 This IETF moderator team ... SHALL moderate all the IETF's various
 current and future participation channels. 

I hope they do, but if they don't, what happens? It starts an appeal?
The moderators are fired? The IETF sinks further into chaos? 

I'd replace the 2119 stuff with normal English or else replace the
boilerplate paragraph 2 with an explanation of what SHALL, MUST NOT,
etc. mean in this context.
```

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I think the 2119 language adds clarity, but I could be convinced to lowercase.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
It's a general problem with process documents, because 2119 was really aimed at technical specs. Maybe this document can set a precedent - define its own terminology text instead of citing RFC2119/8174:

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this
document are to be interpreted  in their normal English sense; they are shown
in uppercase for emphasis and clarity.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @becarpenter would you prepare a PR so we can see how that would look like?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: PR just sent

issues.title: Email suggestions from @MelindaShore
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: Email suggestions from @MelindaShore (sent privately, so not included here)

issues.title: Email suggestions from @mcr
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body:
[Email suggestions](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/wgchairs/p_7CWfwJuyXMhnkQYFxnuNmYrRc) from @mcr:
```
Lars Eggert <lars@eggert.org> wrote:
    > One open question is if WG chairs should retain the task (or at least
    > ability) to moderator their WG lists. We'd be interested in your
    > thoughts here, and of course on anything else related to the document.

They SHOULD retain the ability to moderate their WG lists.
But, hidden in there seems to be the question about whether they ought to
retain the responsibility to do so?

/me goes to read the document.

3-person moderation team... wow. Sounds like a full-time position!

It also seems to require skills and training uncommon to IETF participants.
Does it include reporting of unicast harrassement that may result from publ=
ic
threads?

I think that the moderators should be appointed for three year terms,
(staggered), and that there should probably be a term limit of one term.
[for sanity]

The moderators will need a travel and training budget: the travel budget
specifically to allow for (in-person, intensive, group) training.  Maybe
co-located with I* spring retreat.  Training maybe also to be given to I*.
I don't know what the criteria for the trainers, but I'm sure someone with a
clueful HR friend can find that out.

There is probably need for a (private) case tracking system.
```

issues.title: Email suggestions from @chris-box
issues.author: larseggert
issues.body: Email suggestions from @chris-box (sent privately, so not included here)

issues.title: Definition of "moderation" in the IETF context
issues.author: paulehoffman
issues.body: The draft does not define what the moderator team is and is not allowed to do. This is important because online moderation normally involves removing posting, whereas in the IETF context it only means limiting new posting by an individual. If this draft intends to allow removing of messages from mailing list archives (and I sincerely hope it doesn't!), it needs to say so clearly. If it doesn't intend to allow removing of messages from mailing list archives, it needs to say that so that readers outside the IETF context understand that this is different than all the social media platforms they are familiar with.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: I think we do very occasionally remove messages that are clearly criminal or utterly unacceptable. Certainly we need that option, for legal reasons if no other, but I agree that we need a definition of "normal" moderation.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: There is a TODO in the current revision on whether the document should define some fenceposts for moderation. (Removing messages from the archives is typically done because of legal risks, i.e., is an LLC decision.)

comments.author: paulehoffman
comments.body: Good enough that you have a TODO. I'll close the issue.

issues.title: Scaling (1)
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
The draft has two TODOs that amount to the same thing: "Decide whether moderation rights remain also with WG chairs, list admins,..."

This is a scaling issue: there is no way that a small team can pro-actively moderate hundreds of lists. So it seems evident to me that existing list admins must be the first line (whether for WG or non-WG lists). The only exceptions might be a handful of IETF-wide lists, notably ietf@ and last-call@ (as the draft already says).

Of course that interacts with the BCP83 discussion.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: That WFM, but then we should make it clear(er) that chairs (and community members?) MAY/SHOULD inform the moderators about potentially problematic behavior.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, indeed, I guess it's SHOULD for chairs and non-WG list admins, and MAY for the community.

issues.title: Scaling (2)
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
> This IETF moderator team consists of a small number of individuals (no less than three)

Three is certainly too small. Perhaps change it to "(no less than five)", or omit the parenthesis completely to avoid micromanagement.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
Yes, that trips people up constantly. Maybe
```
This IETF moderator team consists of no less than three individuals,
to establish some minimum basis for consensus-based team decisions
and geographic spread, but realistically needs to have several times that
number of members to spread the moderation load and provide redundancy
in the cases of absences, etc.
```

comments.author: JayDaley
comments.body: If you have several time 3, i.e. 21, then do they all need to reach consensus on any decision?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: I didn't mean we need always a multiple of three, just maybe a bunch more than just three. Point about consensus remains.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: I don't we should set a hard minimum or a hard maximum. Common sense should apply.

issues.title: Define "moderate"
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
We need to precisely define what we mean by "moderate" and "moderation".

See this message for context:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gendispatch/i74Ey8_aFRqekH4n2d6Ha412hSk/

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
Yes, we should be explicit about this being a spectrum all the way from gentle reminders on- and off-list, all the way to suspension of posting rights and other ways of participating/communicating.

We need to make sure the I-D doesn't go to far into policy-setting territory though; that IMO the team needs to do for itself.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Maybe state something like: The term "moderation" can refer both to _preemptive_ moderation, where a moderator reviews messages before release to the mailing list, and _reactive_ moderation, where the moderator intervenes after a message has been sent. The IETF mainly practices reactive moderation, with a spectrum all the way from gentle reminders on- and off-list, all the way to suspension of posting rights and other ways of participating/communicating.

PR?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: WFM. Yes, PR please?

issues.title: Who chooses the moderators?
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
There have been several email comments objecting to "The IETF Chair appoints members of the moderator team." The concern is that this might end up with the Chair being conflicted when a moderation "case" involves the Chair (or maybe the IESG).
Should the moderator team be appointed by a community process? If so, how, since NomCom is already overloaded?

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: I think this is a red herring and the people who hold this objection do so because they want to be able to claim that the IETF Chair is censoring them and the moderator team is compromised when the IETF Chair disagrees with things they say and do.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: That's exactly what they claim. I'm not supporting them necessarily, but should we note this in the draft as an open issue?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
I see no good solution here. And the chair already appoints the current moderator team and the ombudsteam. 

Any machinery we invent (multiple appointment roles/bodies, NomCom, etc.) feels like overkill.

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: Agree with @larseggert.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: We could go to a model that I had been using for those two teams, I.e., have them search and nominate new candidates for the team with the chair merely approving.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
That's good, and should probably be documented for the Ombudsteam too.
Do we also need to discuss how a moderator is removed?
Also we need a conflict of interests section, like section 7 of RFC 7776. What happens if the Chair is involved directly in a moderation "incident"?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
>  Do we also need to discuss how a moderator is removed? 

Either they step down, or the others ask the chair to remove them for <reason>.

>Also we need a conflict of interests section, like section 7 of RFC 7776. What happens if the Chair is involved directly in a moderation "incident"?

The chair should not.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: It shouldn't ever happen. But sometimes bad things do happen...

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Could we see some discussion on #55, specifically whether we need to describe in this I-D how moderators are removed from the team if we go to a "team self-selects, chair confirms" model?

issues.title: Emergency actions for egregious postings
issues.author: becarpenter
issues.body:
I think we should explicitly authorise a few people to take emergency action when a completely unacceptable posting is made (illegal, vulgar, or manifestly harassing). For example, the IETF Chair, the Exec Dir, and maybe a couple of backups, could instruct staff to delete a given message and/or block a given poster, subject to follow-up within 48 hours by the moderation team or to referral to the Ombudsteam.

(I think the staff already have discretion to delete manifest spam, but I'm not sure where that is written down.)

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Agree. But we also need to handle the case where a participation channel gets DoS'ed.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, staff must be able to respond immediately to DoS without any delay.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Based on experience, staff will very often want sign-off from leadership or the community.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, that makes sense, but we need language that allows for true emergencies,

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: LGTM

pulls.title: Add a TODO about whether chairs should be able to moderate still
pulls.author: larseggert

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: WFM

pulls.title: Exclude more roles from moderator team
pulls.author: larseggert

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: I would do s/SHOULD/SHALL/ in the proposed text.

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: I think this is fine!

```suggestion
is joining any such body, they SHOULD step down from the moderator team
```

reviews.author: JayDaley
reviews.body: Works for me.  The community might want it a bit tighter but this is a good starting point

comments.body:
```suggestion
is assuming any such role, they SHOULD step down from the moderator team
```

Suggestion by @coopdanger 
```suggestion
Trust or the LLC Board, as well as LLC staff and contractors SHALL
also be excluded from serving on the moderator team. If a moderator
is assuming any such role, they SHALL step down from the moderator team
```

```suggestion
This IETF moderator team consists of a small number of individuals
(no less than three) that SHALL moderate all the IETF's various
current and future participation channels. At present, those include
mailing lists, chat channels, and in-person and remote meetings.
```

```suggestion
participation channels the IETF offers. It is not expected that the
moderator team will be monitoring every IETF channel, but rather
that participants will proactively flag concerns about disruptive
behavior to the moderator team.
```

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: LGTM

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: Looks reasonable to me

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body: LGTM

reviews.author: jariarkko
reviews.body: Good. One nit: Maybe say "GitHub repositories" instead of just "GitHub" because I think that phrase was used elsewhere in the document.

comments.body:
```suggestion
the IETF or WGs have chosen to employ, such as GitHub repositories,
Wikis, or issue trackers.
```

comments.author: russhousley
comments.body: Mostly, I agree with this change, but the "uniform" application of moderation criteria in #33 does not meld well with these changes.  Discussion is needed.

comments.author: russhousley
comments.body: Brian, then we need to be more clear about what is "uniform".

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: The text says "The moderator team SHALL operate according to a consistent and uniform set of criteria, processes, and actions." I'm just not seeing what is unclear about that sentence .

comments.author: russhousley
comments.body: I do not think there will be "uniform" attention paid to the various channels, and I see this as one way to interpret this sentence.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @russhousley my proposal for #33 is to remove `and uniform`. With that change, is there anything that needs to change wrt this PR?

comments.author: russhousley
comments.body: Works for me.

reviews.author: becarpenter
reviews.body: I respectfully disagree with Russ. I don't think the policy of actively monitoring some lists and not others violates the uniformity of the criteria etc.  It simply recognizes that some lists are more general than others and therefore deserve more attention.

comments.author: russhousley
comments.body: I worry about the use of the word "uniform".  We need to recognize that the energy that a moderator team member has will vary.  $dayjob will place different demands on different days.  I'd prefer wording that aspires to the ideal, but recognizes reality too.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: I don't see Russ's problem with 'uniform' because it refers to criteria etc., not to the moderators themselves. It's true that availability and response times will vary, but that seems like a separate issue.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Regarding "uniform", I tend to agree with Brian. The criteria should be uniform across the org and its channels, but there needs to be an acceptance that moderation actions based on the criteria may have some variance, given that people are involved.

Can we sidestep the issue in this way?
```suggestion
The moderator team SHALL operate according to a consistent
```
wfm

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: All looks OK to me

No, this is a MUST. General moderators cannot understand exactly how unproductive a message is in a specific working group. There are other ways to deal with bad chairs (hopefully a rare thing), so I think the document needs to be clearer here.

Using "SHOULD" here is bad management, because it is not clear.

Editorial: over use of passive voice. "it is expected" is too much.

Can this concern be phrased more directly?

WDYT?
```suggestion
The management and moderation of participation channels associated
with various IETF groups, inculding their mailing lists, chat
channels and in-person, remote, or interim meetings remains primarily a
task of the relevant group's management, such as WG chairs. However,
```

WDYT?
```suggestion
moderators are available for consultation and
assistance should issues arise, and they MAY proactively confer with the group
management over potential patterns of behavior. When moderators
```
wfm
wfm

comments.author: russhousley
comments.body: Seems like the commitment to trained moderators is very helpful.

Releases

3.0.0

3.0.1

  • Fixed download issue for files > 2GB during restore.

3.0.2

3.0.3

3.0.4

3.0.8

  • Fix zstd not working for windows on gnu tar in issues #888 and #891.
  • Allowing users to provide a custom timeout as input for aborting download of a cache segment using an environment variable SEGMENT_DOWNLOAD_TIMEOUT_MINS. Default is 60 minutes.

3.0.9

  • Enhanced the warning message for cache unavailablity in case of GHES.

3.0.10

  • Fix a bug with sorting inputs.
  • Update definition for restore-keys in README.md

pulls.title: Bump actions/upload-artifact from 3 to 4
pulls.author: dependabot
pulls.body:
Bumps [actions/upload-artifact](https://github.com/actions/upload-artifact) from 3 to 4.
Release notes

Sourced from actions/upload-artifact's releases.

v4.0.0

What's Changed

The release of upload-artifact@v4 and download-artifact@v4 are major changes to the backend architecture of Artifacts. They have numerous performance and behavioral improvements.

ℹ️ However, this is a major update that includes breaking changes. Artifacts created with versions v3 and below are not compatible with the v4 actions. Uploads and downloads must use the same major actions versions. There are also key differences from previous versions that may require updates to your workflows.

For more information, please see:

  1. The changelog post.
  2. The README.
  3. The migration documentation.
  4. As well as the underlying npm package, @​actions/artifact documentation.

New Contributors

  • @​vmjoseph made their first contribution in actions/upload-artifact#464

Full Changelog: https://github.com/actions/upload-artifact/compare/v3...v4.0.0

v3.1.3

What's Changed

  • chore(github): remove trailing whitespaces by @​ljmf00 in actions/upload-artifact#313
  • Bump @​actions/artifact version to v1.1.2 by @​bethanyj28 in actions/upload-artifact#436

Full Changelog: https://github.com/actions/upload-artifact/compare/v3...v3.1.3

v3.1.2

  • Update all @actions/* NPM packages to their latest versions- #374
  • Update all dev dependencies to their most recent versions - #375

v3.1.1

  • Update actions/core package to latest version to remove set-output deprecation warning #351

Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot show ignore conditions` will show all of the ignore conditions of the specified dependency - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)

comments.author: dependabot
comments.body: Looks like this PR is already up-to-date with main! If you'd still like to recreate it from scratch, overwriting any edits, you can request `@dependabot recreate`.

pulls.title: Replace BCP14 boilerplate
pulls.author: becarpenter
pulls.body: Just interpret the magic words as plain English, because this is not an interoperability spec. Did not apply bold face.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: Thanks for the PR. Do others think we should do this? (I'm on the fence.)

comments.author: russhousley
comments.body: I guess there is no harm.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: The reason I'm advocating this change is that in the end we need wiggle room in IETF processes, and we can't accept wiggle room in protocol specs - so BCP14 is really the wrong instrument in process documents. (_All_ process documents, not just this one.)

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: PR now also includes note on preemptive vs reactive moderation in response to Joel's comment.

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: One issue: if we leave these terms capitalized in the text, idnits will throw a hissy-fit. It might be better to lowercase and bold them?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
> PR now also includes note on preemptive vs reactive moderation in response to Joel's comment.

Could we do this in a separate PR, so we don't blur which PRs fix which issues?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
1. re lowercase/bold. Good catch... I have no objection to that change.
2. Hmm. GitHub didn't seem to give me a way to make a separate PR. (I use GitHub Desktop on Windows.) So I agree, but I don't know how to do it.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: I've taken the second item out of the PR, to avoid the confusion.

```suggestion
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this
document are to be interpreted in their normal English sense; they are shown
in uppercase for emphasis and clarity.

{:aside}
> TODO: Get feedback from the community whether this redefinition of BCP14
> terms in process documents is something they support.
```

WDYT? Makes it more explicit that we are aware this is unusual at this time.
Yes, good idea. (However, let's avoid bikeshedding this in case it becomes a distraction.)

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @coopdanger please double-check?

reviews.author: coopdanger
reviews.body: Please use alissa.cooper@georgetown.edu, otherwise this looks good.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Yes, update my text as you wish (can't use git from this device)
(via tiny screen & keyboard)
Regards,
        Brian Carpenter

On Mon, 1 Jul 2024, 18:51 Lars Eggert, ***@***.***> wrote:

> ***@***.**** requested changes on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In draft-ecahc-moderation.md
> <https://github.com/larseggert/moderation/pull/52#discussion_r1660552943>:
>
> > +Note that the term "moderation" can refer both to *preemptive*
> +moderation, where a moderator reviews messages before release
> +to the mailing list, and *reactive* moderation, where the moderator
> +intervenes after a message has been sent. The IETF mainly practices
>
> This is written for mailing lists, but the new moderation approach is
> supposed to cover all types of participation channels.
> ------------------------------
>
> In draft-ecahc-moderation.md
> <https://github.com/larseggert/moderation/pull/52#discussion_r1660553787>:
>
> > +intervenes after a message has been sent. The IETF mainly practices
> +reactive moderation, with a spectrum from gentle reminders on- and
> +off-list, all the way to suspension of posting rights and other ways
> +of participating or communicating.
>
> This sounds like we want to retain sticking to mostly reactive moderation?
> I think we want to leave this up to the moderation team to deicide as part
> of their process definition.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/larseggert/moderation/pull/52#pullrequestreview-2150557924>,
> or unsubscribe

> .
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body: @becarpenter proposed some changes.
This is written for mailing lists, but the new moderation approach is supposed to cover all types of participation channels.
This sounds like we want to retain sticking to mostly reactive moderation? I think we want to leave this up to the moderation team to deicide as part of their process definition.

reviews.author: becarpenter
reviews.body: All good for me, except typo s/eam/team/ on line 131

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
" or when the moderator team decides one of their members should be removed"
That needs explanation. Is this a majority vote or unanimous (except for the member in question)? Is it the result of a conflict resolution procedure?  How do members of the community complain about a moderator?
Maybe flag this as an open issue for now?

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
> s this a majority vote or unanimous (except for the member in question)? Is it the result of a conflict resolution procedure? How do members of the community complain about a moderator?

I think this would be a team-internal decision that we don't need to specify in this draft.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: I probably disagree... so pls label it as open for now?

pulls.title: Ombudsteam liaison
pulls.author: larseggert
pulls.body: Came up in email discussion, WDYT?

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: wfm

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body:
Good approach. Just one possible clarifcation:
OLD:
This protection MAY include the need to take emergency moderation actions.
NEW:
This protection MAY include the need for LLC staff to take emergency moderation actions.

(It isn't the Board that will do it personally!)

comments.author: larseggert
comments.body:
> This protection MAY include the need for LLC staff to take emergency moderation actions.

Maybe "...the need for the LLC to take..."? Because it may also not be staff, it could be contractors, etc. under processes defined by the LLC.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, that's fine

comments.author: russhousley
comments.body: Looks right to me.

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: wfm

pulls.title: Add to Security Considerations
pulls.author: russhousley
pulls.body: Limit the likelihood of disruptive behaiviour by one IETF participant from discouraging participation by other IETF participants.

comments.body:
```suggestion
of disruptive behavior by one IETF participant from discouraging
```
But is it really always one? There have been discussions where several participants went over the line, often in response to each other.

Thanks fro fix the typo.  

s/by one IETF participant/by a few IETF participants/

```suggestion
of disruptive behavior by a few IETF participants from discouraging
```

comments.author: becarpenter
comments.body: Yes, just do it
